tips.tip: Bottled spring water is safest option when traveling - Dr. Falkinham's lab testing showed spring water has fewest microbes and almost no NTM compared to other bottled water types
tips.notes: Specific product recommendation from microbiologist who tested various water sources

tips.tip: LifeStraw bottles with 0.2 micrometer filter remove NTM from any water source - allows you to safely fill from tap water in airports, restaurants, or hotels while traveling
tips.notes: Dr. Falkinham confirmed 'we tested' these filters - 0.2 micrometer pore size specifically validated for NTM removal

tips.tip: LARQ UV water bottles kill NTM when used on 3-minute 'adventure mode' cycle - CEO stated equivalent to boiling water for 20 minutes, but water must be kept in dark after treatment to prevent photoreactivation
tips.notes: Dr. Falkinham tested Crazy Cap (similar UV technology) and confirmed kills NTM. LARQ adventure mode 3 minutes vs Crazy Cap 2.5 minutes validated. Critical: NTM can photoreactivate if UV-treated water exposed to sunlight or artificial light - drink directly from bottle, don't pour into glass

tips.tip: When traveling, pack collapsible boiling pot (dual voltage Drizzle pot), collapsible bowl/sieve for soaking in Dawn, small travel bottle of clear Dawn, pre-boiled distilled water in metal bottle, and LifeStraw filtered water bottle in dedicated medical duffle bag
tips.notes: Comprehensive packing list from experienced traveler - medical equipment bag not counted as carry-on when disclosed to airline crew

tips.tip: Baby Brezza compact travel sterilizer fits nebulizer and Aerobika, steams for 10+ minutes then air dries - excellent for hotels/AirBnbs with electricity, much easier than boiling
tips.notes: Baby Brezza ONLY works in US/Canada (110V) - does NOT work in Europe even with voltage converter per multiple patient reports. For Europe, use Drizzle pot (dual voltage) or find microwave for steam bags

tips.tip: Cruises present major equipment sterilization challenges - no microwaves in rooms, hot pots/kettles often confiscated as fire hazard, especially on Virgin Voyages and some other lines
tips.notes: Solutions: (1) Pack LifeStraw pitcher for drinking/rinsing water, (2) Contact special accommodations in advance for permission to bring spring water on board with doctor's letter, (3) Some patients successfully 'hide' Drizzle pot in drawer when not using - risk of confiscation, (4) Consider disposable neb cups pre-sterilized with alcohol/peroxide soak as backup plan

tips.tip: For cruise travel, bring LifeStraw pitcher (packed with socks/underwear to save space) for safe drinking water and rinsing equipment - eliminates need for boiling water source
tips.notes: Successfully used on 10-day cruise. Pitcher method easier than managing hot pot. Get doctor's letter to bring 24-pack spring water on board as alternative

tips.tip: When staying in hotels without kitchen facilities, use collapsible silicone bowl or Stasher bag for soaking equipment in Dawn and tap water, then rinse with filtered water from LifeStraw before sterilizing
tips.notes: Avoid soaking directly in hotel sink (biofilm concerns). Use ice bucket lined with plastic bag or bring collapsible bowl. Stasher bags come in various sizes and work well for travel

tips.tip: UV-sterilized water undergoes 'photoreactivation' when exposed to any light (sunlight or artificial) - NTM cells repair UV damage and become viable again within 90 minutes of light exposure
tips.notes: Dr. Falkinham critical warning: drink UV-treated water directly from opaque bottle, do not transfer to glass or clear container. Photoreactivation system in NTM starts working immediately after UV treatment. Boiled or filtered water not affected by light

tips.tip: For high-altitude travel (7,000+ feet), consider HAST (High Altitude Simulation Test) before trip to determine if supplemental oxygen needed - oxygen saturations can drop into 80s or lower during sleep at altitude
tips.notes: Test involves breathing gas mixture with reduced O2 while monitoring saturations and heart rate. Patient with MAC/bronchiectasis experienced O2 drops to 78% during sleep at 7,000 feet despite passing HAST awake. Portable oxygen concentrator (purse-sized) helpful even if not using constantly - few hits of oxygen throughout day provides energy boost

tips.tip: Vietnam, Cambodia, and other humid tropical estuary-rich regions have extremely high aerosolized NTM levels - Dr. Falkinham recommends wearing N95 mask 'all the time' in these environments
tips.notes: Dr. Falkinham: 'Lots of aerosolized NTM' in humid estuary areas. When asked about constant masking feasibility, he acknowledged 'no easy solution to avoid NTM in aerosols in humid tropical regions.' Dry season (January-February) in Cambodia much safer - almost never rains, cooler, not humid. Mask at riverside only during dry season visits

tips.tip: Rocky Mountain dusty roads pose NTM risk - pine-rich, peat moss-rich soils are preferred NTM habitat. Keep car windows closed and use recirculating air (not fresh air intake) when driving on dusty roads
tips.notes: Dr. Falkinham specific warning about Rocky Mountain dusts. Patient tip: change cabin air filters frequently (every 2 months) when traveling in dry/dusty areas - they get amazingly dirty. Clean air scoop below windshield wipers regularly

tips.tip: When hiking in dusty environments (Rocky Mountains, Sierra Nevada, deserts), wear N95 mask if possible - though Dr. Falkinham noted recirculated car air with closed windows sufficient for driving through dust
tips.notes: Hiking with mask difficult but recommended in high-risk dusty areas. Outdoors generally safer due to air volume dilution, but dusty trails in mountains present concentrated exposure

tips.tip: Travel insurance covering pre-existing conditions essential for international trips - HTH Travel Gap Excursion plan (requires primary insurance like Medicare) and Travel Guard both offer pre-existing condition coverage
tips.notes: HTH FAQ confirms: 'For travelers who enroll in single trip plan option that requires maintaining primary insurance inside U.S., this plan will cover medical treatments for pre-existing conditions.' Travel Guard successfully covered canceled trip claim in 2012

tips.tip: TSA does not require doctor's note for traveling with nebulizer/compressor, but note can be helpful - medical equipment bags with medical luggage tags are not counted toward carry-on limit when disclosed to gate crew
tips.notes: Multiple travelers (2023-2025) report TSA familiar with nebulizers, no issues. Nebulizers, CPAPs exempt from 3-1-1 liquids rule. TSA Cares available for advance coordination. Red medical luggage tags from Amazon help identify equipment bags

tips.tip: Carry backup/spare mesh nebulizer or replacement parts when traveling - mesh nebulizers are delicate and can break, but small enough to easily pack a spare
tips.notes: Patients report mesh nebulizers stopping mid-trip. Some carry two complete Pari Trek systems for longer trips to ensure redundancy

tips.tip: For international travel to Mexico and destinations where distilled water hard to find, pack pre-boiled distilled water in secure metal bottle in checked bag, or freeze and carry-on - allows you to reuse same water for multiple sterilization cycles
tips.notes: Distilled water found at auto parts stores in Mexico. In St. Miguel de Allende: soak in hot water with Dawn 15 min, rinse with bottled spring water, cover with spring water and microwave 5 min, then air dry

tips.tip: When traveling to destinations without boiling/microwaving options, pre-sterilize disposable neb cups with alcohol or peroxide soak, rinse with sterile water, fully dry, and store in individual Ziplocs - provides backup when heat sterilization unavailable
tips.notes: Used as backup plan for Virgin Voyages cruise that doesn't allow hot pots. Disposable cups won't tolerate boiling. Rubbing alcohol soak for 15 minutes suggested alternative though not as reliable as heat sterilization

tips.tip: AirBnbs generally easier than hotels for NTM patients - access to kitchens allows boiling equipment, plus better bathroom ventilation control (can open windows during showers)
tips.notes: Hotels present challenges: limited purified water, poor bathroom ventilation, no microwaves unless requested in advance. Always inquire about microwave availability when making hotel reservations and mention medical need

tips.tip: Remove shower head in hotel bathrooms if showering (or do wet towel baths for short trips) - reduces direct exposure to aerosolized water from showerhead biofilm
tips.notes: Patient packs tiny wrench if can't remove shower head by hand. Open bathroom windows and use fan during/after showers

key_insights: Water safety is paramount - bottled spring water (Dr. Falkinham tested), LifeStraw 0.2Î¼m filters (validated by Dr. Falkinham), and UV bottles (LARQ 3-min adventure mode) are three proven safe options for drinking water while traveling

Equipment sterilization requires advance planning based on destination - Baby Brezza works in US/Canada only, Drizzle pot (dual voltage) for Europe, LifeStraw pitcher for cruises, Medela steam bags for microwaves, or pre-sterilized disposables as backup

Cruise ships present unique challenges - no heat sources in rooms, equipment often confiscated, but LifeStraw pitcher and advance permission for spring water (with doctor's letter) can work around restrictions

Geographic risk assessment critical - humid tropical estuaries (Vietnam/Cambodia rivers) extremely high risk requiring constant N95 masking, while dry season visits (January-February) much safer; Rocky Mountain dusty roads also high risk

UV water sterilization has critical limitation - photoreactivation occurs when UV-treated water exposed to any light, allowing NTM to repair and regrow; must drink directly from opaque UV bottle, never transfer to clear glass

International travel requires equipment redundancy - carry spare mesh nebulizer, extra filters, pre-boiled distilled water, collapsible equipment for soaking/boiling, and verify Baby Brezza won't work outside US/Canada despite voltage converters
High altitude significantly impacts lung function - oxygen saturations can drop into 80s or 70s during sleep at 7,000+ feet; HAST testing before trip determines if supplemental oxygen needed

common_questions.question: What water is safe to drink while traveling?
common_questions.answer: Bottled spring water is safest (fewest NTM per Dr. Falkinham's lab testing). Alternatively, use LifeStraw bottle with 0.2 micrometer filter to make any water safe, or LARQ UV bottle on 3-minute adventure mode (must keep in dark after treatment to prevent NTM photoreactivation). Pasteurization does NOT kill NTM, so pasteurized juices/milk still contain NTM.

common_questions.question: Is cruise travel safe with NTM disease?
common_questions.answer: Cruise travel possible but requires careful planning. Major challenges: (1) Legionella risk from HVAC systems, (2) No microwaves or heat sources in rooms, (3) Hot pots/kettles often confiscated. Solutions: LifeStraw pitcher for all water needs, contact special accommodations for permission to bring spring water with doctor's letter, or risk hiding Drizzle pot in drawer. Consider Legionella exposure risk from humidification systems when deciding if cruise worth it.

common_questions.question: How do I sterilize equipment while traveling?
common_questions.answer: Best options by location: (1) US/Canada hotels - Baby Brezza travel sterilizer, (2) Europe - Drizzle pot dual voltage (Baby Brezza does NOT work despite converters), (3) Cruises - LifeStraw pitcher + Medela steam bags if microwave available, (4) Anywhere - carry pre-boiled distilled water for multiple boiling cycles, collapsible bowl for Dawn soaking, (5) Backup plan - pre-sterilize disposable neb cups with alcohol soak before trip.

common_questions.question: Should I travel to humid tropical destinations like Vietnam or Southeast Asia?
common_questions.answer: Extremely high risk - Dr. Falkinham states 'lots of aerosolized NTM' in humid estuary-rich regions and recommends wearing N95 mask 'all the time.' He acknowledged 'no easy solution to avoid NTM in aerosols in humid tropical regions.' If going anyway, visit during dry season (January-February in Cambodia) when humidity low and mask only at riverside. River cruises particularly high risk.

common_questions.question: Can I use my Baby Brezza sterilizer in Europe?
common_questions.answer: No - multiple patients confirmed Baby Brezza does NOT work in Europe even with voltage converter. Manufacturer states use only in US/Canada and will void warranty if used elsewhere. Use Drizzle pot (dual voltage) for Europe instead, or find microwaves for Medela steam bags.

common_questions.question: Will TSA give me trouble with my nebulizer equipment?
common_questions.answer: No - TSA familiar with nebulizers as of 2023-2025, no doctor's note required (though can be helpful). Medical equipment in bag with medical luggage tags does NOT count toward carry-on limit when disclosed to gate crew. Nebulizers exempt from 3-1-1 liquids rule. TSA Cares available for advance coordination if concerned.

common_questions.question: Is high altitude dangerous with MAC/bronchiectasis?
common_questions.answer: Can be significant issue - oxygen saturations may drop into 80s or even 70s during sleep at 7,000+ feet elevation. Get HAST (High Altitude Simulation Test) before trip to determine if need supplemental oxygen. Even if pass test, portable oxygen concentrator (purse-sized) helpful for energy throughout day. Some patients feel exhausted entire trip at altitude.

common_questions.question: Are dusty roads dangerous for NTM exposure?
common_questions.answer: Rocky Mountain dusty roads pose risk - pine-rich, peat moss-rich soils are preferred NTM habitat per Dr. Falkinham. Keep car windows closed and use recirculating air (not fresh air intake) on dusty roads. Change cabin air filters every 2 months when traveling in dusty areas. Desert dusty trails also concerning for hiking.
